          <h3>Madagascar - Blue Blue Economy MSP</h3>
          <div class="case-location">Madagascar</div>
          <div class="case-years">2019-Present</div>
        </div>
        <div class="case-body">
          <p class="case-body">
          <p class="case-description">National ocean strategy development with focus on sustainable fisheries, aquaculture, and conservation.</p>
          
          <div class="case-section">
            <div class="case-section-title">Focus Areas</div>
            <div class="case-section-content">
              ‚Ä¢ Artisanal fisheries management<br>
              ‚Ä¢ Seaweed and aquaculture zones<br>
              ‚Ä¢ Marine protected areas network<br>
              ‚Ä¢ Capacity development programs
            </div>
          </div>
          
          <div class="case-section">
            <div class="case-section-title">Opportunities</div>
            <div class="case-section-content">
              ‚Ä¢ Growing development financing<br>
              ‚Ä¢ Regional partnerships strengthening<br>
              ‚Ä¢ Technology transfer initiatives
            </div>
          </div>
          
          <div class="case-tags">
            <span class="case-tag">Blue economy</span>
            <span class="case-tag">Capacity building</span>
            <span class="case-tag">Sustainable fisheries</span>
          </div>
        </div>
      </div>
    </div>
  </div>

  <!-- Comparative Analysis -->
  <div class="region-section">
    <h2>üìä Comparative Analysis: Success Factors vs. Barriers</h2>
    
    <table class="comparison-table">
      <thead>
        <tr>
          <th>Factor</th>
          <th>Successful Cases</th>
          <th>Challenged Cases</th>
          <th>Key Lesson for Tanzania</th>
        </tr>
      </thead>
      <tbody>
        <tr>
          <td><strong>Governance Framework</strong></td>
          <td>Clear legal basis, integrated mandates, inter-agency coordination</td>
          <td>Weak coordination, overlapping jurisdictions, political instability</td>
          <td>Develop clear LMSP legal framework at local and national levels</td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td><strong>Community Engagement</strong></td>
          <td>Inclusive, participatory from planning, benefit sharing clear</td>
          <td>Top-down, limited consultation, livelihood concerns ignored</td>
          <td>Ensure community stewardship and livelihood transition support</td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td><strong>Enforcement Capacity</strong></td>
          <td>Adequate monitoring, patrol, penalties, technology use</td>
          <td>Insufficient resources, weak compliance mechanisms</td>
          <td>Build sustainable enforcement systems with community support</td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td><strong>Data & Science</strong></td>
          <td>Science-based planning, regular monitoring, adaptive adjustments</td>
          <td>Limited data, inadequate baselines, no monitoring systems</td>
          <td>Invest in marine data collection and analysis capacity</td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td><strong>Financing</strong></td>
          <td>Sustainable funding mechanisms, diverse sources, long-term commitment</td>
          <td>Project-based, insufficient, dependent on external donors</td>
          <td>Develop diversified funding including blue economy revenues</td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td><strong>Livelihood Alternatives</strong></td>
          <td>Transition programs designed, income support, skills training</td>
          <td>No alternatives, resistance to conservation zones</td>
          <td>Integrate alternative livelihoods in LMSP from the start</td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td><strong>Stakeholder Diversity</strong></td>
          <td>Multi-sector representation, informal sector included, gender balance</td>
          <td>Limited stakeholders, informal economy sidelined</td>
          <td>Ensure inclusive representation of all ocean users</td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td><strong>Adaptive Management</strong></td>
          <td>Regular review cycles, willingness to adjust, learning approach</td>
          <td>Static plans, no feedback mechanisms, implementation inflexible</td>
          <td>Build iterative learning and adjustment into LMSP cycle</td>
        </tr>
      </tbody>
    </table>
  </div>

  <!-- Key Lessons Box -->
  <div class="lessons-box">
    <h3>Key Takeaways for Tanzania's LMSP</h3>
    <ul>
      <li><strong>Start with strong foundations:</strong> Clear governance frameworks, legal backing, and institutional arrangements are non-negotiable (Seychelles, Mauritius models)</li>
      
      <li><strong>Community is central:</strong> MSP success depends on local ownership and livelihood security (Philippines, Canada examples)</li>
      
      <li><strong>Invest in capacity and data:</strong> Scientific monitoring and technical expertise are prerequisites, not luxuries (Australia, Baltic Sea models)</li>
      
      <li><strong>Prepare for livelihood transitions:</strong> Communities dependent on extractive marine uses need real alternatives and transition support (critical lesson from Indonesia, Mozambique)</li>
      
      <li><strong>Enforcement requires resources:</strong> Even well-designed plans fail without monitoring and compliance capacity (key challenge in Indonesia, Philippines)</li>
      
      <li><strong>Multi-sector engagement reduces conflict:</strong> Early and sustained engagement with fishing, tourism, shipping, and conservation sectors prevents future conflicts</li>
      
      <li><strong>Adaptive management is essential:</strong> Plans should evolve based on monitoring, climate change impacts, and stakeholder learning (Australia, Canada approach)</li>
      
      <li><strong>Financing determines sustainability:</strong> Long-term success requires diversified, predictable funding, not just external project support</li>
    </ul>
  </div>

  <div class="challenges-box">
    <h3>Common Pitfalls to Avoid</h3>
    <ul>
      <li>Creating beautiful plans that aren't implemented (Mozambique syndrome)</li>
      
      <li>Excluding informal economy and artisanal fishers from planning (Indonesia, Kenya experience)</li>
      
      <li>Insufficient investment in enforcement capacity (widespread failure)</li>
      
      <li>Ignoring livelihood impacts without providing alternatives</li>
      
      <li>Treating MSP as one-off exercise rather than adaptive, ongoing process</li>
      
      <li>Weak data and monitoring systems leading to uninformed decisions</li>
      
      <li>Fragmented governance with unclear responsibilities and coordination gaps</li>
      
      <li>Insufficient political will or leadership commitment to sustain implementation</li>
    </ul>
  </div>

</div>

<script>
function filterCases(type) {
  const cards = document.querySelectorAll('.case-card');
  const buttons = document.querySelectorAll('.filter-btn');
  
  // Update active button
  buttons.forEach(btn => btn.classList.remove('active'));
  event.target.classList.add('active');
  
  // Filter cards
  cards.forEach(card => {
    if (type === 'all' || card.dataset.type === type) {
      card.style.display = 'block';
    } else {
      card.style.display = 'none';
    }
  });
}
</script>
